pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:0.2: The nuns’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:0.4: The sub-chapter on the dark of the night
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:1.2: On one occasion the nun Caṇḍakāḷī quarreled with the nuns and she cried after repeatedly beating herself.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:1.3: The nuns of few desires complained and criticized her,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:1.4: “How can Venerable Caṇḍakāḷī cry after repeatedly beating herself?” …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:1.5: “Is it true, monks, that the nun Caṇḍakāḷī did this?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:1.8: “… How can the nun Caṇḍakāḷī cry after repeatedly beating herself?
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:1.9: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:1.10: And, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule thus:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:1.11: ‘If a nun cries after repeatedly beating herself, she commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:2.1.4: … The nun who has been given the full ordination by both complete Sanghas through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of nun is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:2.1.7: If she cries after repeatedly beating herself, she commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:2.1.8: If she beats herself, but does not cry, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:2.1.9: If she cries, but does not beat herself, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:2.2.2: if she cries, but does not beat herself, because of loss of relatives, loss of property, or loss of health;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:2.2.4: if she is the first offender.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:2.2.5: The tenth training rule is finished.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:2.2.6: The second chapter on darkness is finished.
